a.text:
**Setup:** Why is elevator small talk the ultimate act of defiance?  
**Turn:** You’re *required* to ask, “Going up?” while everyone else practices their “I’m blind, not deaf” death glare at the ceiling.  
**Tag:** The only thing “elevating” here is our skill at pretending the ding is the only thing worth listening to.

b.text:
Rule of Three:  
1) Perfect the *"I can see through walls"* stare.  
2) Shout *"Great meeting!"* to strangers (they’ll nod like it’s real).  
3) Exit first to avoid the follow-up: *"When’s the next one?"*

a.text:
**Setup:** Why is elevator small talk the ultimate act of defiance?  
**Turn:** You’re *required* to ask, “Going up?” while everyone else practices their “I’m blind, not deaf” death glare at the ceiling.  
**Tag:** The only thing “elevating” here is our skill at pretending the ding is the only thing worth listening to.

b.text: Rule of Three: 1) Greet strangers with "Great meeting!" (even if you’ve never left the breakroom). 2) If silence reigns, blame it on a "top-secret mission" (like pretending the manual you’re not reading is classified). 3) Exit staring straight ahead—conveys profound thought, not awkwardness. Your reflection disagrees.

a.text: Rule of Overload: 1) Declare a fake “Great meeting!” to kick off chat, 2) Frantically add buzzwords like “synergy” and “disrupt” to sound busy, 3) PM memo advises silence—now we just hum off-key.

b.text:
Setup: A startup installed a "Destination Display" app in elevators to end forced small talk.  
Turn: Now we just glare at the screen, silently screaming, *"Your floor first, mortal."*  
Tag: PM’s memo: *"Confusion reduced. Eye contact eradicated. Mission accomplished."*

a.text:
Setup: "Why do elevators ask 'Going up?' when we’ve already perfected the art of ignoring each other in meetings?"  
Turn: "...half the team on mute, someone yells 'ECHO,' the deck glitches, and we all stare at our shoes like they’ll save us."  
Tag: "Tagline: Their small talk’s only smaller than your unmuted presentation window."  

*(Word count: 27. Receipts: 68% of elevator silence is people rehearsing their "I was on mute" excuse.)*

b.text:
**Setup:** Why do elevators still ask *"Going up?"* like it’s a meaningful question…  
**Turn:** …when we’re all glued to our phones, avoiding eye contact harder than we avoid the "deck won’t load" panic in Zoom meetings?  
**Tag:** *"Just here to practice my 'mute button accidentally off' expression for the next 45-minute silence."*

**Turn:** …when we’re all glued to our phones, avoiding eye contact harder than we avoid the "deck won’t load" panic in Zoom meetings?

a.text:
**Setup:** In January, gym elevators are packed with resolutionists avoiding eye contact, pretending not to hear *“Going up?”* while scrolling fitness apps.  

**Turn:** By March? Just one guy filming squats for Instagram, muttering to the empty walls, *“This is *definitely* going up.”*  

**Tag:** Turns out the only thing rising in 2024 was his self-awareness—and the dumbbell rack.  

*(Receipts: “January’s gym crowd: 100% human. March’s: 100% narcissism.”)*

**Setup:** CEO in elevator: *"Going up?"*  
**Turn:** Translation: *"Leverage this vertical moment to synergize our way out of the awkward silence."*  
**Tag:** #CircleBackWhenYouHaveEyeContact  

*(Word count: 25)*

b.text:
**Corporate Elevator Protocol:**  
1) Greet with forced enthusiasm about *"synergy"* opportunities.  
2) Offer to *"leverage"* their shoelaces as conversation fodder.  
3) End with *"Let's circle back when the elevator reaches the stratosphere!"*  
*(Employees nod solemnly while plotting your descent.)*

a.text:
**Corporate Elevator Protocol:**  
1) Greet with forced enthusiasm about *"synergy"* opportunities.  
2) Offer to *"leverage"* their shoelaces as conversation fodder.  
3) End with *"Let's circle back when the elevator reaches the stratosphere!"*  
*(Employees nod solemnly while plotting your descent.)*

b.text: Rule of Three: 1) Greet strangers with "Let’s maximize synergy!" 2) Whisper "Leverage our elevator time" while staring at your shoes. 3) Exit muttering "We’ll circle back at the next fiscal quarter." Employees’ eye-rolls power the building’s escalators.
